description: On April 2nd 2020, The Ministry of Health in Palau issues a press release urging the public to get factual information on Covid-19 from trusted sources, promoting the usage of the the MOH Hotline, bringing to attention the “widespread creation, publication and sharing on social media of false, fraudulent and unsubstantiated content about claims of vaccines and cures for Covid-19 across the internet”. Trusted sources cited are as follows: The Palau Ministry of Health, US Center for Disease Control and Prevention, World Health Organization.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: The Government of Palau implements the restriction of entry of cruise ships into any Palau port from March 1 to 31, 2020. description: Ministry of Health announced on 6 August, 2020 that essential workers from other countries shall undergo 7 days of mandatory quarantine upon arrival in Palauin a government designated facility, and tested on days 1 and 7 during quarantine. If tests are negative on day 7, they will be released to work, but subjected to quarantine in place for 7 more days, where they are only allowed to move from place of residence to their work, and wear masks at all time. These individuals will be tested again on day 14, and allowed to move freely in the community if test results are negative.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: All countries
target_who_gen: Essential workers (please note their occuption in the text entry where applicable)

description: Ministry of Health of Palau issued Directive No. 13-21 on 6 May, 2021 where it says that the crew of any commercial aircraft or vessel entering the Republic must provide negative PCR COVID-19 test results and proof of full COVID-19 vaccination and/or provide official documentation on infection control measures implemented for aircraft operations and health management protocols for personnel. The policy starts on 22 May, 2021 and unless cancelled, revoked or re-issued, shall remain in effect for 90 days from effective date.

description:
Palau Ministry of Health and Human Services issued an directive on 12 August, 2021 which says that from 12 August, 2021, travelers entering Palau should do 3 steps.
1. Travellers must submit proof of complete COVID-19 vaccination with final dose administered 14 days prior to departure to the Republic. Vaccine received must be approved or authorized for emergency use by either the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) or the World Health Organization (WHO). *For commercial air travel, travellers must submit proof to the airline. 
2. All Travelers must also provide proof of either: a. A negative result of a COVID-19 PCR test, and such test must be taken within 3 days prior to departure from the point of origin to the Republic; or b. Documentation of recovery from COVID-19 which includes proof of a recent positive viral test and a letter from a healthcare provider or a public health official stating that you have recovered and are cleared to travel. 
3. All Travelers shall be COVID tested on the 5th day following their arrival to the Republic and are required to follow the Mitigation Orders issued upon arrival.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries

description:
Palau Ministry of Health and Human Serviced issued a directive no. 27-21 which says that starting from 12 August, 2021, residents from Authorized Jurisdictions, those that have been approved by the President can enter Palau under 4 special conditions:
1. Submit a negative result of a COVID-19 PCR test and such test must be taken at the airport up to five 5 hours before departure from the Authorized Jurisdiction.
2. No travel history to destinations outside of the Authorized Jurisdiction within the last 14 days prior to departure from the Authorized Jurisdiction.
3. No prior history of COVID-19 infection, no close contact with any person who is under investigation for COVID-19, no close contact with laboratory-confirmed COVID19 case, and no person under a self-isolation, home quarantine, or self-monitoring order for the last two months.
4. All Travelers shall be COVID tested on the 5th day following their arrival to the Republic if the Traveler is present in the Republic on the fifth day.
The poicy lasts untill 12 November, 2021.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Travel History Form (e.g. documents where traveler has recently been)
target_geog_level: All countries
target_who_what: Foreign Residents (Foreign Nationals Residing in the Country)
target_who_gen: Other workers where the distinction between essential or non-essential is not explictely made (please note the occupation in the text entry)

description:
Palau Ministry of Health and Human Services issued an directive no. 07-22 which includes following entry requirements.
1.Travelers must submit proof of complete COVID-19 vaccination with final dose administered at least 14 days prior to departure to the Republic.
2. Negative COVID-19 PCR Test or Documentation of Recovery. All Travelers must also provide proof of either: a) A negative result of a COVID-19 PCR test and such test must be taken within 3 days prior to departure from the point of origin to the Republic; or b) A negative result of a COVID-19 antigen test and such test must be taken within 1 day prior to departure from the point of origin to the Republic; or c) Documentation of recovery from COVID-19 which includes proof of a recent positive viral test and a letter from a healthcare provider or a public health official stating that traveler has recovered from COVID-19 and is cleared to travel. 
3. All Travelers shall be COVID tested following their arrival to the Republic as deemed appropriate by MHHS and are required to follow all requirements stated in the Mitigation Orders issued upon arrival.
The policy takes effect from 16 January, 2022 and lasts until 16 April, 2022.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries
target_who_gen: People of a certain age (please note age range in the text entry)

1.Travelers must submit proof of complete COVID-19 vaccination with final dose administered at least 14 days prior to departure to the Republic.
2. Negative COVID-19 PCR Test or Documentation of Recovery. All Travelers must also provide proof of either: a) A negative result of a COVID-19 PCR test and such test must be taken within 3 days prior to departure from the point of origin to the Republic; or b) A negative result of a COVID-19 antigen test and such test must be taken within 1 day prior to departure from the point of origin to the Republic; or c) Documentation of recovery from COVID-19 which includes proof of a recent positive viral test and a letter from a healthcare provider or a public health official stating that traveler has recovered from COVID-19 and is cleared to travel. 
3. All Travelers shall be COVID tested following their arrival to the Republic as deemed appropriate by MHHS and are required to follow all requirements stated in the Mitigation Orders issued upon arrival.
The policy takes effect from 16 January, 2022 and lasts until 16 April, 2022.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries
target_who_gen: People of a certain age (please note age range in the text entry)

description:
Palau Ministry of Health and Human Services issued an directive no. 07-22 which includes following entry requirements.
1.Travelers must submit proof of complete COVID-19 vaccination with final dose administered at least 14 days prior to departure to the Republic.
2. Negative COVID-19 PCR Test or Documentation of Recovery. All Travelers must also provide proof of either: a) A negative result of a COVID-19 PCR test and such test must be taken within 3 days prior to departure from the point of origin to the Republic; or b) A negative result of a COVID-19 antigen test and such test must be taken within 1 day prior to departure from the point of origin to the Republic; or c) Documentation of recovery from COVID-19 which includes proof of a recent positive viral test and a letter from a healthcare provider or a public health official stating that traveler has recovered from COVID-19 and is cleared to travel. 
3. All Travelers shall be COVID tested following their arrival to the Republic as deemed appropriate by MHHS and are required to follow all requirements stated in the Mitigation Orders issued upon arrival.
The policy takes effect from 16 January, 2022 and lasts until 16 April, 2022.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: 3G: Must be either (i) vaccinated (ii) have a valid COVID-19 negative test within a certain time frame or (iii) recovered from COVID-19
target_geog_level: All countries
target_who_gen: People of a certain age (please note age range in the text entry)

description:
Palau Ministry of Health and Human Services issued an directive no. 07-22 which includes the following travel entry for residents from authorized Jurisdictions under 4 special conditions:
1. Submit a negative result of a COVID-19 PCR test taken within 3 days prior to departure or a negative result of a COVID-19 antigen test taken within 1 day prior to departure to the Republic
2. No travel history to destinations outside of the Authorized Jurisdiction within the last 14 days prior to departure from the Authorized Jurisdiction
3. No prior history of COVID-19 infection, no close contact with any person who is under investigation for COVID-19, no close contact with laboratory-confirmed COVID-19 case, 3 and no person under a self-isolation, home quarantine, or self-monitoring order for the last two months
4. Testing After Arrival. All Travelers shall be COVID tested on the fourth (4th) day following their arrival to the Republic.
The policy takes effect on 16 January, 2022 and lasts until 16 April 2022.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries
target_who_gen: Other workers where the distinction between essential or non-essential is not explictely made (please note the occupation in the text entry)

description: Ministry of Health and Human Services of Palau issued directive 100-22 on 1 July, 2022, where travelers must be fully vaccinated to enter the Republic. Travelers must submit proof of complete COVID-19 vaccination with final dose administered at least fourteen (14) days prior to departure to the Republic. For commercial air travel, travelers must submit proof to the airline. For chartered vessels, travelers must submit directly to MHHS. This policy starts on 9 July, 2022 until further notice.

description: All Palauan ministries, agencies, and civil service partners are called to focus their efforts to prevent the entry of COVID-19 into the Republic as of March 17, 2020. All government manpower and resources shall be prioritized to implement prevention, preparation, screening, containment, mitigation, and treatment efforts led by the Ministry of Health and National Emergency Committee. The Ministry of Health or National Emergency may request the assistance of any government employee; any requested employee shall be transferred or temporarily assigned, as appropriate, to provide the requested assistance.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: “The Bureau of Public Services in Palau shall establish a Covid-19 stipend as additional compensation for frontline workers engaged in activities which present an increased risk of exposure to Covid-19.” The stipend is available only to frontline workers for time spent in activities that actually risk exposure to Covid-19. The stipend takes effect immediately and remains available until this order is amended or rescinded.

description: On March 20th 2020, An executive order from the president of Palau established "a joint leadership working group to develop and and recommend measures to mitigate the social and economic impacts of the Covid-19 pandemic." Meetings by this group occur weekly and aim to look beyond emergency response measures- focusing on long term concerns by assessing the health, safety, social and economic impacts of the covid-19 pandemic, making recommendations to support, relieve and ensure… this group is active until disbanded.

description: Effective April 22nd, 2020, the Palau government passed HB 10-131-14S, SD2 the COVID-19 Presidential Borrowing Act of 2020. The Act authorizes president Tommy E. Remengesau to borrow 60 million dollars from any financial institution(s) or foreign government(s) in order to stave off economic decline for the fiscal year of 2020, 2021, and the potential future. It is stated the money is to be used to keep current social programs running while specifically saving the borrowed funds for the next administration.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: Issued April 8th, the Ministry of Health in Koror, Palau, authorized the isolation and quarantine measures to control the Coronavirus Disease 2019. Any person who is suspected of being exposed is expected to go into quarantine for the mandatory 14 days. Additionally, any persons coming from Guam, China, Japan, Korea, or the Philippines will be considered to have been exposed and be quarantined for the 14 days.

description: Palau Ministry of Health issued a directive on 6 May, 2021, in which  any person proven or strongly suspected to be infected with COVID-19 shall be isolated for a period up to 14 days. Infection may be proven or strongly suspected based on a presumptive test result, and/or a confirmatory test result by means of authorized assays for viral testing include those that detect SARS-CoV-2 nucleic acid or antigen. The policy starts from 22 May, 2021 and unless cancelled, revoked or re-issued, shall remain in effect for 90 days from effective date.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Palau Ministry of Health and Human Services issued an directive no. 27-21, which says the following: any person determined to have been exposed to COVID-19, any person who has had direct contact with a person infected by COVID-19, any person who has had indirect contact with COVID-19, such as contact with potentially contaminated surfaces, shall undergo mandatory quarantine for a period up to 14 days. They must be either at an isolation facility or at home at the discretion of the
Director of Public Health. The policy takes effect on 12 August, 2021 and lasts until 12 November, 2021.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
25 April, 2023. 
Palau Ministry of Health and Human Services issued an directive 001-23, which says that any person determined to have been in close contact with someone with COVID-19 shall self-monitor for a period of 5 days and follow applicable guidelines as deemed necessary by the Ministry of Health and Human Services.
The policy lasts until further notice.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: People with certain health conditions (please note which health conditions in the text entry)

description: In Palau, Ministry of Health Directive No. 114-120 issued on May 11th 2020, authorized the The Belau National hospital (BNH) emergency operations plan remain activated while the BNH regulations shift as follows: "chronic disease clinics and elective surgeries may resume, Maintain physical distancing in clinic and healthcare settings, in-patient visiting hours reduced to 1 hour a day, admitted patients allowed 1 caretaker at a time, Clinic hours to be staggered with regular cleaning and disinfecting to be maintained, persons age 55+ or anyone with underlying medical conditions are recommended to avoid visiting the BNH unless seeking critical medical care, Maintain health screening, surveillance and monitoring at all BNH ports of entry".
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: In Palau, Ministry of Health Directive No. 114-120 issued on May 11th 2020 enforced the following general restriction for the opening of businesses, worksites and restaurants: “ Resume regular operating hours, Engage in Virtual meetings whenever possible, Maintain engineering and environmental controls including barriers, regular cleaning and disinfecting, Monitoring employees and patrons, forbidding entry of sick people, Encourage staying home when sick and providing sick leave to compliant employees, Use your own pen and stationary, Maintain proper food safety practices, Encourage employees and patrons to practice proper hand hygiene and respiratory etiquette”
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)

description: The Government of Palau limits Belau National Hospital in-patient visiting hours to one hour per day.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: Palau is offering a compressed work schedule that "shall be voluntary, and shall allow employees to work 40 hours per week on a schedule other than the basic workweek" for any office of the executive branch of the national government between July 1st 2020 to December 31st 2020. allowing "the republic of Palau to continue to grow healthier as a nation and develop its overall social and cultural structure... to engage in other activities aimed at bettering the employees physical and/or mental health during the Covid-19 pandemic". Compressing work schedules will not only “motivate employees to be more satisfied, focused and efficient” but will also “realize savings in fuel and vehicle maintenance costs for those offices that provide employees with transportation free transportation... as well as savings in utility costs when offices are closed a day more than usual”
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: On April 6th 2020, The Palau Ministry of Health recommends the "Use of Cloth Face Coverings/Masks, Especially in Areas of Significant (COVID-19) Community-Based Transmission", noting that "Cloth face coverings/masks are not a substitute for social distancing. It is still very important to maintain 6-feet social distancing to slow the spread of the virus

description: Effective April 6th, 2020, the Ministry of Health in Palau issued the recommendation of wearing cloth face coverings/Masks, especially in Areas of Significant (COVID-19) Community-Based Transmission. Additionally specified not to use surgical or N-95 respirators as those are deemed critical supplies for healthcare workers.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
